text_image_relationship.layout_style: Full-page illumination composed of two superimposed circular medallions set within a decorative frame, no accompanying text on the recto.

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf reserved for heavenly background and haloes; ultramarine and vermilion alternate in apostles’ robes to create rhythmic color contrast; layered pigments with white lead highlights define folds and faces; green used sparingly for secondary garments; consistent palette across both scenes ensures unity; original colors remain vibrant with minimal lead white darkening.

features: Frame of flowing foliate scrolls unifying both scenes
Figures arranged in a semicircle around focal point
Strong horizontal axis formed by benches and table

decorative_elements: Floral and foliate scroll border with punched white dots
Draped curtain motif in upper scene
Alternating red and blue quarters in frame background

drawing_technique.line_style: Fluid quill pen outlines in dark brown ink with fine internal detail lines for drapery and facial features.
drawing_technique.shading_method: Subtle white lead highlights on folds and flesh; minimal hatching, relying on pigment layering.
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling without linear perspective; overlapping figures and receding bench imply shallow depth.

reading_order: Top roundel first, then bottom roundel

scene_relationships.subject: Christ washing the feet of the twelve apostles
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Precedes the institution of the Eucharist at the Last Supper by demonstrating Christ’s humility and service.
visual_connections: Same circular gilt frame encloses each scene
Apostles wear identical robe colors in corresponding positions
Flowing scroll border continues uninterrupted between medallions

scene_relationships.subject: The Last Supper with Christ and the apostles, including Judas kneeling at the table’s foot
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Concludes the Maundy Thursday sequence by depicting the sacramental meal initiated by Christ.
visual_connections: Consistent gold background unites both scenes
Horizontal bench in upper scene echoes the long table below
Halos rendered in identical style and pigment

visual_continuity: Burnished gold leaf background across both roundels
Ultramarine and vermilion robe palette repeated
White lead highlighting on drapery folds
Dark brown ink outlines defining figures

content_theme.scene_description: In the upper roundel Christ, identifiable by his nimbus and central placement, kneels before an apostle seated on a low bench. He holds the disciple’s right foot over a shallow basin, pouring water from a jug held in his left hand. The seated apostle inclines, his green robe and red undergarment articulated with white highlights. Eleven additional apostles stand behind in semicircular grouping, their varied hair and beard patterns meticulously delineated in brown ink and white lead. The draped red curtain behind suggests an inner room. Feet rest on a footstool and the basin rim is gilded. The spatial arrangement is shallow: overlapping figures create depth, but all are nearly equal in scale, emphasizing communal unity. Each apostle’s tunic and cloak reveal lapis lazuli and vermilion layering techniques. The decorative frame of scrolling acanthus leaves in blue, red, green, and gold punctuated with white dots encloses the scene. Compositionally, the viewer’s eye is drawn from Christ’s bowed figure through the circle of apostles to the lifted hand of one disciple at the back.

technical_features.material: Premium calfskin vellum with uniformly smooth, well-pumiced surface; sheet from quaternion gathering with ruled layout visible under magnification.
technical_features.preservation_condition: Excellent overall preservation; vibrant pigments with minimal flaking; slight gold abrasion at medallion rims; no modern retouching visible.
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso under gold leaf creating low relief
Fine underdrawing in brown ink visible under UV
Punch-work stippling in gold leaf background
Regular ruling for frame and roundel placement

secondary_functions: Visual reminder of Maundy Thursday rites
Memory aid for Holy Week preaching

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This full-page double-roundel illumination likely originates from a mid-13th-century French liturgical manuscript, possibly produced in a Parisian workshop under royal patronage. The pairing of the Mandatum and Last Supper reflects the liturgical emphasis on Maundy Thursday rites and underscores the theological link between Christ’s humility and the institution of the Eucharist. The use of sumptuous ultramarine and burnished gold leaf, alongside precise quill underdrawing and gesso relief, signals a high-quality production intended for an elite ecclesiastical audience. The balanced two-tier grid composition demonstrates an innovative yet tradition-rooted approach to narrative display, while the continuous acanthus border reflects evolving Gothic decorative conventions. Iconographically, the juxtaposition of foot washing and the eucharistic meal conveys a programmatic message of service preceding sacramental unity, aligning with Cistercian and Dominican devotional currents of the period. Comparative analysis reveals affinities with the Psalter of Blanche of Castile in palette and execution, suggesting shared workshop practices or itinerant illuminators. This illumination thus embodies the intersection of liturgical function, technical mastery, and sophisticated iconographic design characteristic of high medieval manuscript art.
